SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Interface SQLSession

All Superinterfaces:
AutoCloseable
public sealed interface SQLSession extends AutoCloseable

An SQLSession is used to initiate and prepare the execution of SQL. It allows you to set SQL template variables within the SQL and then obtain a SQLStatement object that can be used to set (a.k.a. "bind") the named parameters within the SQL. The difference between template variables and named parameters is explained in the comments for the SQL interface. The SQLSession implementation you get from SQL.basic()) does not support template variables. This leaves you no choice but to retrieve a SQLStatement from it straight away.

Probably the most common use case for using template variables is to parametrize the ORDER BY column and sort order ("ASC" or "DESC"). Therefore the SQLSession contains a few specialized set methods specifically for this purpose. These methods assume that the SQL template contains a template variable named "sortColumn" for the ORDER BY column(s), and a template variable name "sortOrder" for the sort order.

The difference between the SQLSession you get from SQL.template() and the one you get from SQL.skeleton() is that with the latter, named parameters are extracted from the SQL at the very last moment, just before you retrieve a SQLStatement from the session. Thus, if the SQL contained template variables, and you set one or more of them to text values that again contain named parameters, these, too, will be available for binding in the SQLStatement.

An SQLSession is not thread-safe and should generally not be reused once you have obtained a SQLStatement object from it.

  • Method Details

    • set

      default SQLSession set(String varName, Object value) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets the value of the specified template variable. The value will not be escaped or quoted. If the value is an array or collection, it will be "imploded" to a string, using "," (comma) to separate the elements in the array or collection. This method will throw an UnsupportedOperationException for basic SQL sessions since these are not based on Klojang Templates.
      Parameters:
      varName - the name of the template variable
      value - the value to set the variable to.
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.basic() method
      See Also:
      • Template
      • RenderSession.set(String, Object)
      • ArrayMethods.implode(Object[])
      • CollectionMethods.implode(Collection)

    • quote

      default SQLSession quote(String varName, Object value) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets the specified template variable to the escaped and quoted version of the specified value. The value is escaped and quoted using the quoteValue(Object) method. Use this method if the source of the value is unknown to prevent SQL injection.
      Parameters:
      varName - the name of the template variable
      value - the value to set the variable to
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.basic() method
      See Also:
      • quoteValue(Object)

    • setValues

      default <T> SQLSession setValues(BeanReader<T> reader, List<T> beans) throws UnsupportedOperationException

      A specialised SQL template method, aimed at facilitating batch inserts. The SQL template must contain a nested template named "values". This template will be repeated for each of the beans or records in the provided list. This is best illustrated using an example: 

      
 record Person(Integer id, String firstName, String lastName, int age) {}
 // ...
 List<Person> persons = List.of(
    new Person(null, "John", "Smith", 34),
    new Person(null, "Francis", "O'Donell", 27),
    new Person(null, "Mary", "Bear", 52));
 // ...
 SQL sql = SQL.template("""
    INSERT INTO PERSON(FIRST_NAME,LAST_NAME,AGE) VALUES
    ~%%begin:values%
    (~%firstName%,~%lastName%,~%age%)
    ~%%end:values%
    """);
 try(SQLSession session = sql.session()) {
  session.setValues(Person.class, persons).execute();
 }

      The above code snippet will execute the following SQL: 

      
 INSERT INTO PERSON(FIRST_NAME,LAST_NAME,AGE) VALUES
 ('John','Smith',34),
 ('Francis','O''Donell',27),
 ('Mary','Bear',52)
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the beans or records to persist
      Parameters:
      reader - a BeanReader for the beans or records to persist
      beans - the beans or records to persist
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.basic() method
      See Also:
      • SQLInsert.insertBatchAndGetIDs(List)
      • SQLInsert.insertBatchAndSetIDs(String, List)

    • setOrderBy

      default SQLSession setOrderBy(Object sortColumn) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets a template variable named "sortColumn" to the specified value. This presumes and requires that the SQL template indeed contains a variable with that name. This is a convenience method facilitating the most common use case for template variables: to parametrize the column(s) in the ORDER BY clause.
      Parameters:
      sortColumn - the column(s) to sort on
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.basic() method

    • setSortOrder

      default SQLSession setSortOrder(Object sortOrder) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets a template variable named "sortOrder" to the specified value. This presumes and requires that the SQL template indeed contains a variable with that name. The provided value supposedly is either "ASC" or "DESC". The value may also be a boolean, in which case true is translated into "DESC" and false into "ASC". This is a convenience method facilitating the most common use case for template variables: to parametrize the sort order for the column(s) in the ORDER BY clause.
      Parameters:
      sortOrder - the sort order
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.basic() method

    • setDescending

      default SQLSession setDescending(boolean isDescending) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets a template variable named "sortOrder" to "DESC" if the argument equals true, else to "ASC".
      Parameters:
      isDescending - whether to sort in descending order
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.basic() method

    • setOrderBy

      default SQLSession setOrderBy(Object sortColumn, Object sortOrder) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets the sort column and sort order of an ORDER BY clause.
      Parameters:
      sortColumn - the column to sort on
      sortOrder - the sort order
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.basic() method

    • setOrderBy

      default SQLSession setOrderBy(Object sortColumn, boolean isDescending) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets the sort column and sort order of an ORDER BY clause.
      Parameters:
      sortColumn - the column to sort on
      isDescending - whether to sort in descending order
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.basic() method

    • quoteValue

      default String quoteValue(Object value) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Escapes and quotes the specified value. More precisely:
      • If the value is null, the literal string "NULL" (without quotes) is returned.
      • If the value is a Number, a Boolean or a SQLExpression, the value is returned as-is. No quoting will take place.
      • Otherwise the value is escaped and quoted according to the quoting rules of the target database.
      Use this method if the value comes from outside your program to prevent SQL injection.
      Parameters:
      value - the value to be escaped and quoted
      Returns:
      the escaped and quoted value
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.basic() method

    • quoteIdentifier

      default String quoteIdentifier(String identifier) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      If necessary, quotes the specified identifier (e.g. a column name or table name) according to the quoting rules of the target database.
      Parameters:
      identifier - the identifier to quote
      Returns:
      the quoted identifier
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.basic() method
      See Also:
      • Statement.enquoteIdentifier(String, boolean)

    • execute

      void execute()
      Executes the SQL. You can call this method either if the SQL is completely static, or if you have set all template variables and the SQL does not contain any named parameters. If the SQL does contain named parameters, you will first have to bind them. Call prepareInsert(), or prepareUpdate() to obtain a SQLStatement that enables you to bind the named parameters. Although you could call this method for SQL SELECT statements, it does not make much sense because this method does not return any feedback from the database.

    • prepareQuery

      SQLQuery prepareQuery()
      Returns a SQLQuery instance that allows you to provide values for named parameters ("binding") and then execute the query.
      Returns:
      a SQLQuery instance

    • prepareInsert

      default SQLInsert prepareInsert()
      Returns a SQLInsert instance that allows you to provide values for named parameters ("binding") and then execute the INSERT statement. Auto-generated keys will be made available to the client.
      Returns:
      a SQLInsert instance

    • prepareInsert

      SQLInsert prepareInsert(boolean retrieveAutoKeys)
      Returns a SQLInsert instance that allows you to provide values for named parameters ("binding") and then execute the INSERT statement.
      Parameters:
      retrieveAutoKeys - whether to retrieve the keys that were generated by the database
      Returns:
      a SQLInsert instance

    • prepareUpdate

      SQLUpdate prepareUpdate()
      Returns a SQLUpdate instance that allows you to provide values for named parameters ("binding") and then execute the UPDATE or DELETE statement.
      Returns:
      a SQLUpdate instance
